content: This report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2020, comparing enacted FY2019 appropriations, the Trump Administration's FY2020 budget request, and the enacted appropriations measures. It also provides additional informational resources on DHS appropriations and a list of CRS policy experts for consultation. The CRS reports on homeland security appropriations track legislative action and congressional issues related to DHS appropriations, focusing on discretionary funding amounts. These reports do not analyze specific issues related to mandatory funding or follow other legislation related to DHS programs, activities, or fee revenues. Budget authority is established through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation and determines the amounts available for federal agencies to spend. The Antideficiency Act prohibits federal agencies from spending more than the budget authority allows. Budget authority is established through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation, determining available amounts for federal agencies to spend. The Antideficiency Act prohibits agencies from obligating more funds than authorized by Congress, which may be indefinite in amount. Budget authority can be on a one-year, multiyear, or no-year basis. Budget authority can be provided on a one-year, multiyear, or no-year basis.
